comments.commentBody:
Ronald Cohen:

You are assuming that the federal government is capable of doing it more efficiently and that one solution would ever be acceptable to all states. This is a big country with a diverse set of values and a strong libertarian streak.

Great side; good main for a vegan. I used 1/2 the dressing, and it was just the right amount. Julienned the carrots in a cuisinart. Used just a little boiling water, so that in 2 minutes the green beans would cook dry, rather than boiling them in more water and then throwing the vitamins down the drain. Added thin- sliced, fresh shallots straight from our CSA, because I had them.

and Elke
MTF Tobin- my Norene Gilletz cookbook says I tsp. is equal to 5 ml. and 1 tbsp. is equal to 15 ml.
I rarely measure, I learned the " schutt erein " method........

.
Has anyone had anything approaching success in figuring out a July 14 connection to today's honorand?

The closest I've come as far as significant days in his bio is July 16.

Perhaps one of the constructors will stop by and enlighten us. "Joe D. from Brooklyn" (Joe Dipietro) left a brief note on the blog for his puzzle. And speaking of constructors, "success" anagrams to SEUSS and C.C. (yesterday's constructress, familiarly).

Will rely on Elke and Dr. Robi re the formula to convert CC/ml to TSPS. If presidential candidate Lincoln Chafee has his way, we will adopt cc/ml and drop TSPS. to measure liquid volume.

There is no message, because in the history of widely publicized settlements of "police brutality/civil rights" cases, this is a very cheap settlement.

Way back in the mid 1990's LA's famous police beating victim, Rodney King and his lawyer collectively got $5.5 Million and King did not die.

He claims he became a cop to help people.  Well her certainly helped Garner...right to his grave.  Although Im sorry this has become a racisl incident which t wasn't.  If a white person weighing over 400 lbs had been at that spot on that day, he would have encountered the same grisly fate.  You don't agree?  Go back and read about the attack by some other of these animals masquerading as law enforcement on the 82 year old Chinese gentleman on the upper west side.  Nothing happened to these so helpful cops either.

So what is going on in the mind of Daniel Pantaleo the apparent choke holder? According to another newspaper, he gets police protection and wants to get back to work doing, I suppose, what he did before.

He has apparently also been sued twice. Given what he has done in public and on video, if he was working for a corporation he would have been booted long ago. What in the world holds police to such low standards?

If you have a gun and are allowed to arrest people or even to kill them you should be held to the highest of standards. Don't police care about the poor image of their profession? Have they just given up?
You think he wanted to leave his children? You think he wanted to die? You are a sick individual.

The lawyer gets $3,000,000 and the relatives get a once in a lifetime bonanza and the victim is dead.  Only in the US would money be thrown at a problem with no positive conclusion.  Too bad the taxpayers of NY or the Police Union preferably, couldn't cough up some money and create a city park in honor of the deceased.  Instead the lawyer will buy a bigger condo and the family will blow their share on who knows what.
Who is supposed to enforce the law??

Does anyone else notice the similarity between police officers and the upper-level employees of banks and other financial institutions. In both cases, whether we call the money handed over by the relevant institution a fine or a civil settlement, the institution, be it a bank or a Wall Street firm, pays someone a whopping big sum of money base upon the wrongdoing committed by the employees of the institution. But unlike what happens if you or I go out and steal money or kill someone, no one gets punished for that wrongdoing in a criminal trial. The policeman who killed Eric Garner in a case labeled by the medical examiner as a homicide does not even go to trial. The employees of the banks and Wall Street firms are never brought before the bar of justice for the milions and millions of dollars they stole from the general public and the ensuing near collapse of the US economy. But if you or I walk into a convenient store and swipe a pack of cigarettes, we can expect to be prosecuted. Seems to me that Lady Justice is certainly blind. Or is it just that she turns a blind eye to the wrongdoing of the privileged members of our society, like misbehaving policemen, bankers, and Wall Streeters?

I am glad to hear the family will be spared the ordeal of litigation. I hope the hospital that employed the EMT's who did nothing to help Eric Garner are likewise held to account.
One also hopes that the Justice Department brings charges against the officer who is responsible for Mr. Garner's death as well.
I also am happy t hear thast Mr. Garner's non-marital daughter who is only a year old will also receve a substantial portion of the settlement; it came as a surprise to learn he had an infant daughter at the time of his death.
Esaw Garner and hed children have been the face of his family for the past year. Not sure why it has only recently come to light that he had a babg girl by the name of Legacy.

Last, Scott Stringer is doing a great job as NYC Comptroller. He did the right thing here. Had the Corp Counsel gotten involved aftef a lawsuit was filed, they would have dragged it out until the plaintiffs could not bear it any longer.
It would have eventually settled years later.

No family should have to endure the anguish and anxiety of a prolonged wrongful death trial. But a part of me thinks that the city should have tried this case (with a guaranteed minimum award to the family) and let all of us learn what happens on the street.   Polic protocols must be changed.  Despite repeated public police involvement in civilian deaths, it's not happening.  Time is up.
How much of the 5.9 million will the  officer pay who choked Garner to death? Otherwise the payment is punishment to citizens for hiiring and continuing to employ rogue cops. Is that fair?

Greece needs to amend the deal (ultimatum) presented to them - since they have followed forced austerity as prescribed, and are actually running a primary surplus, but after 5 years their economy is smaller and the VSP's from the north prescribed yet more of the same medicine, Greece needs to be saying " What if your prescription still doesn't work; what if we continue to get smaller and the debt burden gets more insurmountable, then what " ?

Greece should include a provision in their legislation that says if they continue to follow the VSP's prescription, and things get worse, that the debt burden gets chopped in half - if things go badly enough, the debt should be entirely erased.

How else to combat bad prescriptions, applied over and over, yielding bad results for everyone except the creditors who are tossing out prescriptions ?

Voo-doo must be confronted and called out everywhere it is found :)

Have you ever thought to serve the pesto ingregents in small dishes and allow everyone to build a burger. That's a great way to cut the calories.
We use romaine as a wrap instead of a bun. Slice the mushroom. Shred lettuce and toss the basil with it. Roast garlic and serve to spread. Roast pine nuts, walnuts and others. Crack them and serve. Put cheese on the side.
Let them choose their own calories. It's good.

Calories for the recipe are seriously undercounted. The olive oil itself would provide 180 calories per serving. The recipe is  closer to 425/serving, if you don't use "heaping" tablespoons of pesto. Will go higher with the heaping tablespoons.

I look at the 1167 comments for your previous blog and the comments rapidly appearing for this one, Roach Motel Economics, and can only conclude that many people want more information on what happened last weekend as well as why it happened.  NPR this afternoon mentioned how some European countries are talking about humanitarian aid to Greece, but have found no reporting in the other US media.  And I am horrified with those who believe the Greeks somehow deserve what is happening.

Mexican's. They are no dummies. Build a house and dig a tunnel.

If they do not do they kill their families. Best leverage,compliance you can get.

Same thing for the Prison guards,management.

Time to build the wall. Not us them. Mexico. 1/4 mile back from our border. They have a huge advantage. No EPA rules,reports,no workman comp,no labor laws. Unlimited workforce. No little animal problems,no homes or business owners to beg.

Steel from China and Korea duty free.

Cut off all aid and add a 35% tariff on manufactured products entering the USA till it is built. Exempt food stuff.

90 days and it will be complete. Monitor our side,buffer zone no mans land with electronics.

Time to make some progress here with Free Trade.

I just don't think so.  He has more money than the desert has sand.  I don't have any idea how to hold him, but if the Mexican Police can get hold of his money, they can put him on a island off the coast, and that will make it one tough tunnel to dig.

Mexicans are only now becoming cynical of President Nieta?  I was cynical after his lackluster response to the murder of students in Iguala last year by the city's Mayor.  He should have rolled in with tanks, put that place under marshal law, replaced its entire police department, and called new elections.  It could have been an important show of force against corrupt politicians and gangsters.  But no.  He says he wants to confront corruption, but it's really just more of the same.

Not much?

You're kidding, right?

Who do you think supplies all the cartels with lethal weaponry?? They are all from the US!!

What do you mean you're glad his family will be well provided for? People on here need some perspective. Mr. Garner had 31 prior arrests. He was at no point, a functional citizen in society. That and he was in extremely poor health; obese among other things. He was by definition; unemployable. At no point did be make a concerted effort to seek out employment or join even the lowest rank of society and become an honest tax payer. Spare me the socioeconomic hoopla, that because he is Black, he is disadvantaged. That same racist tune postulated by the sold called "none racists" on the New York Times and elsewhere is tiresome.

This payment is a momental slap in the fact to the average citizen of New York City.

Traintime
Have you not watched the video!
Anyone trained to deal with an unarmed person knows that you DO NOT USE AN ILLEGAL CHOKEHOLD to take someone down.

If I had been on the jury and seen the video, I would have given more than that to the victim's family.
Zejee, he was in fact selling loosies please get your facts straight before you comment.

I am glad that Mr. Garner's family will be well-provided for. That said, the sum awarded cannot bring Mr. Garner back and does not mitigate the harm inflicted by misguided policing.

I hope that more sensitive policing will result from Mr. Garner's death.

Greece doesn't have to accept the deal. They can leave the Euro, default on most of their debts, clean up their insolvent banks, and take the Argentina route back. Europe seems to be OK if they go that way. If the Greeks were confident in their ability to build new institutions that does seem like a better medium-term option, but Tsipras didn't want to do that.

He wants to stay in Europe. Maybe he is representing the will of his people, but if so the emotional negotiating strategy and waiting until l the last minute to cave (when he had 0 leverage the whole time) was designed to express the emotions of the people not to get the best possible outcome for them. Certainly the Germans are not one block and instead of trying to help the left wing Germans build a coalition among the parts of the German government who might help with a stimulus argument, his behavior, and esp the pointless referendum 1) empowered the moralistic wing of the German govern and 2) damaged his economy some more so the hole is now deeper.

In Greece the standard of living has certainly gotten worse and will continue to deteriorate, but the problem in part is that they were artificially good in 2007. The government was borrowing money to spend on the giant public sector--for a long time--and this was inflating the standard of living in the country. The problem is that whatever path forward the Greeks take that standard of living is going to drop. And that will be painful.

Greece should not accept a one-sided deal from northern VSP's that prescribes more of the same austerity that hasn't worked in the past, just applied harder and worse.

Instead, Greece should tell the North, " Fine, you've presented us with an ultimatum, but if we follow your (voo-doo) austerity prescription and things continue to get worse, as they have over the last 5 years in austerity, then our debts will be cut in half - and if things go truly badly, then the debts are erased entirely. This is the only way to make sure creditors aren't just posturing and pontificating. "

Voo-doo austerity that has made things worse over the last 5 years for Greece has almost no chance of making things better in the next 5 years, without debt reduction; the creditors should be wiped out if they are proposing plans that are un-workable, designed to be moralistic totems instead of sound actual economic policy.

This guy should have been locked up like Hannibal Lector.  His 'escape' only stirs the ashes of the 43 students murdered by his ilk and the officials who protect them.  God Bless America.  We have problems, but not like this.
Now you know who runs the country, The Narco-politicians,,,,,,,,The enemy  # 1 in Mexico is the police believe it or not, but is true,,,
Who allowed any kind of construction within a mile from a major prison?

For the second time in two days, the NYT's publishes the Mexican government's own explanation of the missing 43 students in Ayotzinapa as if it were fact. In an article otherwise critical and questioning - why cling to this version of events which has been widely dismissed in Mexico and abroad?

"Investigators revealed that a mayor, who had been working with a criminal organization in the area, had handed the students to the gang, which then killed them and burned the remains."
